questions.text: A neuron receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons can be best described as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Convergence

Explanation:

  • Convergence refers to a situation where multiple presynaptic neurons (in this case, 150 sensory neurons) send signals to a single postsynaptic neuron.
  • This leads to the summation of inputs, allowing the postsynaptic neuron to integrate and respond to multiple inputs.
  • In this clinical scenario, the neuron is receiving 400 inputs from 150 sensory neurons, which fits the definition of convergence.

Incorrect Options:

Divergence (Option A): Occurs when one neuron sends its output to multiple neurons, not the other way around.

Feedback inhibition (Option C): This refers to a regulatory mechanism where the output of a neuron inhibits its own activity or the activity of upstream neurons

Feedforward system (Option D): This refers to a mechanism where a neuron sends signals that facilitate or prepare for a future action, often without the influence of previous outputs

questions.text: At point “C”, what is the length-tension relationship of the sarcomere
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -

Explanation:

The marked point on the graph represents Optimal Overlap, where actin and myosin filaments align ideally, enabling the maximum number of cross-bridges to form; therefore, option D is the most accurate.

  • Optimal overlap refers to the ideal length of a muscle sarcomere where the maximum number of actin and myosin cross-bridges can form, resulting in maximal force generation during contraction.

The length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle:

  • Optimal Length: The sarcomere length that produces maximum tension is between 2.0 and 2.2 μm.

  • Cross-Bridge Formation: Tension is greatest at this optimal length because cross-bridge formation between actin and myosin filaments is maximized.

  • Short Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are shorter than optimal, excessive overlap of actin filaments limits cross-bridge formation, reducing tension.

  • Long Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are longer than optimal, cross-bridge formation decreases as actin and myosin filaments overlap less, leading to reduced tension.

  • Maximum Stretch: At lengths around 3.6 μm, the sarcomere can rupture due to excessive stretching.

questions.text: In malignant hyperthermia, a genetic mutation in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) leads to a life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic agents. What is the primary ionic abnormality caused by this receptor defect?

choices.text: Increased sodium influx into the muscle cell
Increased potassium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Increased chloride efflux from the muscle cell
Increased calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Increased calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum:

Explanation:

Malignant Hyperthermia is a life-threatening genetic disorder triggered by anesthetic agents like halothane or succinylcholine, caused by mutations in the RYR1 gene that affect the ryanodine receptor in skeletal muscle.

  • Cause: Mutation in the RYR1 gene → defective ryanodine receptor in skeletal muscle.
  • Trigger: Exposure to volatile anesthetics (e.g., halothane) or succinylcholine.
  • Mechanism: Excessive calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum → sustained muscle contraction and hypermetabolism. (Option D)
  • Symptoms:
    • Rapid increase in body temperature
    • Muscle rigidity
    • Tachycardia
    • Hypercapnia
    • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Complications: Acidosis, renal failure, death if untreated.

Incorrect Options:

Increased sodium influx into the muscle cell (Option A): Not the primary defect in malignant hyperthermia; sodium handling isn't directly affected by the RYR1 mutation.

Increased potassium uptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (Option B): Potassium is not actively stored or regulated in the sarcoplasmic reticulum in this context.

Increased chloride efflux from the muscle cell (Option C): Chloride channels help stabilize the resting membrane potential but are not involved in the pathogenesis of malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man wakes up after sleeping with his arm draped over a chair and complains of pain. Which of the following accurately describes the order of susceptibility of nerve fibers in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A > B > C

Explanation:

The order of nerve fiber susceptibility to compression is: A > B > C

Susceptibility to

Local Anesthesia

Pressure

Hypoxia

Aγ and Aδ >> Aα and Aβ >> B >> C

Aα > B > C

B > A > C

questions.text: What best describes step 3 in the given diagram?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential is maintained by the Na-K pump

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Efflux of K ions

Explanation:

Step 3 – Repolarisation occurs as voltage-gated K⁺ channels open, causing K⁺ efflux, which restores the membrane potential toward its resting level.

Process

Membrane Potential Change

Ion Movement/Channel Activity

Threshold Impact

Resting Potential

~ -65 mV

Higher K⁺ inside than outside

Neutral

Depolarization

Na⁺ influx (channels open)

Possible Action Potential

EPSP

More positive

Positive ions enter

Triggers Action Potential if threshold reached

Repolarization

Returns to -65 mV

from peak of depolarization

Returns to resting state

Hyperpolarization

More negative than -65 mV

Cl⁻ enters or K⁺ exits (channels remain open)

Less likely to fire immediately

IPSP

More negative

Negative ions enter or K⁺ exits

Inhibits action potential

Incorrect Options:

Efflux of Na ions (Option A): Not involved in repolarisation; Na⁺ channels are already inactivated.

Influx of Na ions (Option B): Happens during depolarisation, not repolarisation.

Resting membrane potential is maintained by the Na-K pump (Option D): True in general, but not specific to the repolarisation phase.

questions.text: The contraction phase of a single muscle twitch lasts 40 milliseconds. What is the tetanization frequency required to produce a sustained contraction in this muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct answers- C)25Hz

Explanation

  • Tetanization occurs when successive muscle twitches summate to produce a sustained contraction, meaning the muscle doesn't have time to fully relax between stimuli. For this to happen, the frequency of stimulation must be high enough that the next stimulus arrives before the muscle twitch from the previous stimulus has completely relaxed.
  • If the contraction phase of a single muscle twitch lasts 40 milliseconds (ms), then to achieve summation and eventually tetanus, the stimuli must be delivered at intervals shorter than or equal to this relaxation time.

 

The frequency (Hz) is the reciprocal of the time period (in seconds).

Time period (T) = 40 ms = 0.040 seconds

Frequency (f) = 1 / T = 1 / 0.040 Hz

Frequency (f) = 25 Hz

Therefore, a frequency of 25 Hz or higher would be required to produce a sustained contraction (tetanus) in this muscle.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describes the mechanisms involved in depolarization, repolarization, and hyperpolarization during a skeletal muscle action potential?


	Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
	Depolarization due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
	Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
	Repolarization due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
	Hyperpolarisation due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) 1,3 and 5 are correct

Explanation:

 

 

Phase

Membrane Potential

Na+ Channels

K+ Channels

Resting State

Polarized (-70 mV)

Closed

Less negative, towards 0 mV.

Rapidly opening, then inactivating

Open

questions.text: In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine, and ryanodine receptors are coupled by?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Mechanically

Explanation:

  • In skeletal muscle, dihydropyridine and ryanodine receptors are coupled mechanically. This coupling mechanism allows the voltage change across the muscle cell membrane to trigger the opening of the ryanodine receptor, releasing calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm, which is essential for muscle contraction.

Sarcotubular System:

  • The Sarcotubular system is composed of the L tubule T tubule .
  • The T-tubule contains a L-type voltage gated Calcium channel, known as the DHPR (dihydropyridine receptor channel).
  • The L-tubule contains a calcium channel known as RyR ryanodine receptor channel).

  • After the membrane depolarization, the DHPR channel will undergo conformation changes to extend one arm towards the RyR channel, which will lead to a mechanical interaction between the two channels.

questions.text:
Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: A- Z line B- A band C-I band D-H band
A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band
A-M line B-I band C-H band D-I band
A-M line B-I band C- A band D- H band

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band

 

Explanation:

  • A (Z line): Dark vertical line marking the boundary between sarcomeres and anchoring actin filaments.
  • B (I band): Light region containing only thin actin filaments; shortens during contraction.
  • C (A band): Dark region containing thick myosin filaments, with actin overlapping; remains unchanged in length.
  • D (H band): Lighter central part of A band with only myosin filaments; disappears during contraction.

Sarcomere Structural Components

Region

Description

Z line

Defines sarcomere boundary, actin attachment

I band

Actin-only region, shortens during contraction

A band

Myosin-containing region, remains constant

H band

Myosin-only zone in A band, disappears in contraction

questions.text: What is the underlying mechanism of action for pain reduction by transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gate Control Theory

Explanation:

  • The Gate control theory, developed by Patrick Wall and Ronald Melzack, explains that pain perception is modulated by the interaction between different nerve fibers in the spinal cord.
    • Large-diameter Aα and Aβ fibers inhibit the transmission of pain signals from small-diameter C fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord by activating inhibitory interneurons, effectively "closing the gate" to pain.
    • TENS works by stimulating these large-diameter fibers, reducing pain perception through this mechanism.

Incorrect Options:

Central inhibition (Option A): Refers to the reduction of pain processing at the central nervous system level, but TENS primarily works via spinal cord modulation (gate control), not central inhibition.

Desensitization (Option B): Involves the reduction in the sensitivity of pain receptors over time, but is not the primary mechanism of TENS.

Descending inhibition (Option D): Involves pain inhibition through descending pathways from the brain, which is a different mechanism from gate control.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction?

1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not essential for contraction

2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria

3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • Extracellular Ca2+ is not essential for skeletal muscle contraction as calcium primarily comes from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR).
  • The release of Ca2+ from the SR is crucial for muscle contraction, while voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on the sarcolemma play a role in excitation-contraction coupling.

Sequential events during muscle contraction

Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

An action potential triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca²⁺) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm of the muscle cell. (Statement 2 ruled out)

Binding of calcium ions to troponin C

Calcium ions bind to troponin C on the thin filaments, causing a conformational change in the troponin complex.

Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin

The conformational change in the troponin complex moves tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing the myosin heads (with ADP and Pi bound) to attach to the exposed binding sites on actin.

Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees

The myosin head pivots from a 90-degree angle to a 45-degree angle, pulling the actin filament toward the center of the sarcomere. ADP and Pi are released during this movement.

Detachment of the myosin head from actin

A new ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.

Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head

The ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP and Pi, providing energy to re-cock the myosin head back to the 90-degree position, ready for another cycle of contraction.

 

(Statement 4 ruled out)

questions.text: What mediates the Inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) Golgi tendon

Explanation:

  • Inverse stretch reflex, also known as the inverse myotatic reflex/autogenic inhibition, is mediated by the Golgi tendon organs (GTOs).
  • Golgi tendon organs are specialized sensory receptors located in the tendons near the junction of muscles and tendons.
  • When the muscle contracts and applies tension to the tendon, the GTOs are activated. They sense changes in tension and send inhibitory signals to the spinal cord, which in turn inhibits the motor neurons innervating the muscle. This reflex helps prevent excessive tension and potential damage to the muscle and tendon by inhibiting further contraction.
  • Main outcome: Relaxation of the muscle in response to a strong stretch.

Reflex arc

Receptor

Golgi Tendon Organs (GTOs).

Location of Receptors

Found at the junction of muscles and tendons.

Afferent Fiber

Type Ib afferent fibers.

Stimulus

Increased tension within the muscle-tendon unit.

Response

Inhibition of the alpha motor neurons leading to muscle relaxation.

Function

Prevents damage to muscles and tendons from excessive force or tension.

Muscle spindle (Option B): The muscle spindle is responsible for the stretch reflex, also known as the myotatic reflex, which detects changes in muscle length and initiates a reflex contraction of the muscle.

Unmyelinated C fibres (Option C): They are associated with pain perception and are not specifically involved in the inverse stretch reflex.

Dorsal Column (Option D): It refers to a pathway in the spinal cord involved in transmitting sensory information related to touch, proprioception, and vibration. It is not directly involved in mediating the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: What causes the detachment of myosin from actin filaments?

choices.text: Attachment of ATP to the myosin head
Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasm

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Attachment of ATP to the myosin head

 

Explanation:

The detachment of myosin from actin filaments occurs when ATP binds to the myosin head.

After the power stroke (when myosin pulls on actin), ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) are still bound to the myosin head. When ATP binds to the myosin head, it causes the myosin head to detach from actin. This detachment allows the muscle to relax and prepares the myosin head for the next contraction cycle.

 

Stimulus (e.g., hormones, neurotransmitters, or stretch)

￬

Calcium channels open, allowing Ca²⁺ to enter the cell from the extracellular fluid.

￬

Formation of Calcium-calmodulin complex

(Intracellular Ca²⁺ binds to calmodulin)

￬

The Ca²⁺-calmodulin complex activates myosin light chain kinase (MLCK)

￬

MLCK phosphorylates the light chains of myosin

￬

Phosphorylated myosin interacts with actin filaments.

￬

The interaction between myosin and actin causes contraction

  • Smooth muscle can maintain contraction with less energy expenditure than skeletal muscle (Latch-bridge mechanism).
  • Relaxation: Occurs when Ca²⁺ is pumped out of the cell or back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and myosin is dephosphorylated.

 

Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasm (Option B): Calcium ions are essential for muscle contraction. They bind to troponin, causing a conformational change that exposes myosin-binding sites on actin. In the absence of calcium, the cross-bridge cycle halts, preventing the power stroke.

 

Conformational change in Troponin T (Option C): Troponin T helps regulate tropomyosin's position on actin, which controls the binding of myosin to actin, facilitating muscle contraction.

 

Dissociation of ADP and Pi (Option D): The dissociation of ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) from myosin triggers the power stroke, driving muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which statement is accurate about the nerve action potential curve provided?

choices.text: The threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to the opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is a refractory period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Point B to D is a refractory period

Explanation:

  • The given graph represents an action potential curve of a nerve.
  • Point B to D represents the refractory period, a phase during which a second action potential is impossible or difficult to trigger. This period includes the absolute refractory period (impossible to trigger a second action potential) and the relative refractory period (a second action potential can be triggered but requires a stronger stimulus).

Phase

Membrane Potential

Na+ Channels

K+ Channels

Resting State- Point A (Option A ruled out)

Polarized (-70 mV)

Closed

Closed

Depolarization (Rising Phase)

Less negative, towards 0 mV

Rapidly opening, then inactivating

Slowly opens

Overshoot (Peak)

Briefly positive (+35 mV)

Inactivated

Open

Repolarization (Falling Phase)- Point C to D (Option C ruled out)

Returning to negative

Inactivated

Open

After-hyperpolarization

More negative

Closed

Slowly closing

Return to Resting State- Point E (Option B ruled out)

Returning to -70 mV

Closed

Closed

Propagation of Action Potential:

  • Mechanism: Action potentials travel along the nerve fiber without diminishing. Depolarization at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions.
  • All-or-Nothing Principle: An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength.

Refractory Periods: (Option D)

  • Absolute Refractory Period: Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing another action potential.
  • Relative Refractory Period: Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarization.

Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibers, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy.

Energy Dependence: Na⁺-K⁺ Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP.

Factors Influencing Excitability:

  • Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺): Low extracellular Ca²⁺ increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na⁺ channels; high Ca²⁺ decreases excitability.
  • Local Anesthetics: Block voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.text:
What contributes to the latent period of muscle twitch?

 

1. Neuromuscular transmission

2. Excitation contraction coupling

3. Reuptake of calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum

4. Transmission impulse from nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,4

 

Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular transmission initiates muscle contraction by releasing acetylcholine (ACh) at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Excitation-contraction coupling propagates the action potential along the T-tubules and triggers Ca²⁺ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Transmission impulse from the nerve carries the action potential along the motor neuron to stimulate the muscle.

Latent Period of Muscle Twitch

Process

Role in Latent Period

Neuromuscular transmission

ACh release at the neuromuscular junction triggers muscle fiber depolarization.

Excitation-contraction coupling

Action potential spreads through T-tubules, leading to Ca²⁺ release.

Nerve impulse transmission

Action potential travels along the motor neuron to reach the muscle.

1, 2 (Option A): Incorrect because nerve impulse transmission is a crucial step before neuromuscular transmission and excitation-contraction coupling.

1, 2, 3 (Option B): Incorrect because reuptake of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum occurs during the relaxation phase, not the latent period.

1, 4 (Option C): Incorrect because excitation-contraction coupling is essential for Ca²⁺ release, and without it, contraction cannot occur.

questions.text: Which of the following changes occurs during muscle contraction while exercising?

choices.text: M length increase and I decrease

questions.solution:
Answer: C) I length decrease

 

Explanation:

During muscle contraction, the sarcomere shortens, leading to specific changes in the myofilament structure:

 

  • A-band: The length of the A-band remains the same during muscle contraction because it corresponds to the length of the myosin filaments, which do not change.
  • H-band: The H-band decreases or disappears as the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments during contraction, reducing the region where only myosin is present.
  • I-band: The length of the I-band decreases as the sarcomere shortens and the actin filaments overlap more with the myosin filaments.
  • M-line: The M-line becomes more prominent as it marks the central point of the sarcomere where the thick filaments are anchored.

 

 

M length increase (Option A) is incorrect because the M line does not change in length during contraction.

 

A length decrease (Option B) is incorrect because the A band remains constant (myosin filament length does not change).

 

M length increase and I decrease (Option D) is incorrect because while I band decreases, the M line does not change in length.

questions.text:
Sequence the events in neuromuscular action potential conduction: 


	Sodium channels open in the end plate
	Calcium enters at the nerve end plate
	Release of acetylcholine
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2 → 3 → 1:

Events in Neuromuscular Action Potential Conduction:

2. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate: Calcium ions enter the nerve terminal when an action potential reaches the nerve end. This influx of calcium is crucial for the subsequent release of neurotransmitters.

3. Release of acetylcholine: The entry of calcium ions into the nerve terminal triggers the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

1. Sodium channels open in the end plate: The binding of acetylcholine to receptors on the muscle end plate causes sodium channels to open, leading to an influx of sodium ions into the muscle cell and generating an action potential in the muscle.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and C are incorrect as given above

questions.text: A man presents to the hospital with complaints of drooping eyelids (ptosis) and increasing eye irritation. He notes that his symptoms worsen as the day goes on, particularly during outdoor activities. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myasthenia gravis

Explanation:

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that leads to weakness of the voluntary muscles, particularly affecting the eyes and face.
  • The condition often worsens with activity and improves with rest. Symptoms commonly include ptosis, diplopia (double vision), and generalized muscle weakness.

Disorders related to Neuromuscular junction:

Feature

Myasthenia Gravis

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS)

Primary autoantibody target

Acetylcholine receptors

Voltage-gated calcium channels

Pathophysiology

Reduced postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors

Decreased presynaptic acetylcholine release

Fatigue pattern

Worsens with activity

Improves with brief exercise.

(Option A)

Reflexes

Normal or mildly reduced

Reduced or absent may improve after exercise.

Repetitive nerve stimulation

Decremental response.

Incremental response.

 

Response to edrophonium

Improves symptoms.

Little to no improvement.

Botulism Toxicity (Option C): is caused by botulinum toxin, which inhibits acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. It results in muscle weakness, but symptoms typically include descending paralysis and can affect multiple muscle groups. While ptosis may occur, botulism generally presents with more widespread weakness and not specifically with worsening symptoms throughout the day.

Tetanus Toxicity (Option D): Tetanus is caused by the toxin of Clostridium tetani, leading to severe muscle spasms and rigidity. Symptoms often include lockjaw, muscle stiffness, and generalized spasms, rather than ptosis or symptoms that worsen with the day.

questions.text: Voltage-gated calcium channel present on T-tubule is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dihydropyridine receptor

Explanation:

  • The dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), also called the L-type calcium channel, is found in the T-tubule membrane near the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) in muscle cells.
  • When an action potential travels along the T-tubule, DHPR channels open in response to voltage changes, allowing calcium ions to enter the sarcoplasm.

Sarcotubular System:

  • The Sarcotubular system is composed of the L tubule and T tubule.
  • The T-tubule contains an L-type voltage-gated Calcium channel, known as the DHPR (dihydropyridine receptor channel).
  • The L-tubule contains a calcium channel known as RyR ryanodine receptor channel (Option D)

 

 

 

SERCA pump (Option A): Sarcoplasmic/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase is situated on the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) membrane in muscle cells, moves calcium ions (Ca2+) from the cell's cytoplasm into the SR lumen, against their concentration gradient.

Troponin-myosin complex (Option B): Troponin, a protein complex on muscle actin filaments, comprises three subunits: troponin C, troponin I, and troponin T. This complex regulates muscle contraction and relaxation by modulating actin-myosin filament interaction in response to intracellular calcium changes.

questions.text: How does the muscle spindle detect muscle length during muscle contraction?

choices.text: Stretch receptor in the muscle belly

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stretch receptor in the muscle belly

Explanation: The muscle spindle is a specialized sensory receptor located within the muscle belly. It detects changes in muscle length (stretch) and velocity to asses the joint's position.

Muscle spindle receptor

  • Muscle spindles are sensory receptors located within the bulk of skeletal muscles, specifically within the muscle belly.
  • They are spindle-shaped and play a crucial role in detecting changes in muscle length and velocity, which helps in sensing the position of joints.

Structure of muscle spindles:

  • Intrafusal fibers:
    • These are the specialized muscle fibers that make up the muscle spindle.
    • Unlike typical muscle fibers, they are non-contractile in the central region and are surrounded by a capsule.
    • Intrafusal fibers are red due to their high mitochondrial content.
  • Extrafusal fibers:
    • Surrounding the muscle spindles, these are the standard contractile fibers of the skeletal muscle.
    • They are white and responsible for generating force and movement.

Function:

  • Length detection:
    • Muscle spindles detect changes in muscle length.
    • When a muscle is stretched, the muscle spindle is also stretched, which activates the sensory nerve endings within the spindle.
  • Velocity detection:
    • The spindles can also detect the rate of change of muscle length (velocity of stretch), providing important information for maintaining posture and coordinating movements.

Stretch receptor on the tendon (Option A): The Golgi tendon organ, not a muscle spindle, is located in the tendon and detects changes in muscle tension rather than length. ​

Golgi tendon organ (Option C): As mentioned, this organ detects muscle tension and not length. ​

Mechanoreceptor in the joint capsule (Option D): These receptors detect changes in joint position and pressure but do not directly monitor muscle length during contraction.

questions.text: Which protein does calcium bind to during smooth muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calmodulin

Explanation:

  • In smooth muscle contraction, calcium binds to calmodulin, which then activates myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK). This activation is crucial for muscle contraction.

Mechanism of smooth muscle contraction:

  • Smooth muscle can maintain contraction with less energy expenditure than skeletal muscle (Latch-bridge mechanism).
  • Relaxation: Occurs when Ca²⁺ is pumped out of the cell or back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and myosin is dephosphorylated.

Troponin (Option B): is a calcium-binding protein found in skeletal muscle, not smooth muscle. In skeletal muscle, calcium binds to troponin to initiate contraction.

Topoisomerase (Option C): is an enzyme that helps manage DNA supercoiling during replication and transcription. It does not interact with calcium during muscle contraction.

Actin (Option D): is a filamentous protein that forms the backbone of the thin filaments in muscle fibers. While actin interacts with myosin for muscle contraction, it does not bind directly with calcium.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury, and his serum K+ level was found to be 6.5 mEq/L. What will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient?

choices.text: First becomes more positive then negative

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Becomes more positive

Explanation:

  • In hyperkalemia, where serum potassium levels are higher than normal (as in this patient with muscle injury), the concentration gradient of potassium ions across the cell membrane changes.

RMP in hyperkalemia, hypokalemia and hypocalcemia

Condition

Hyperkalemia

Hypokalemia

RMP

Depolarized (Decreased RMP)

Hyperpolarized (Increased RMP)

Explanation
  • Increased extracellular potassium reduces the gradient for potassium to exit the cell, causing depolarization.
  • The resting membrane potential becomes less negative than the typical -70 mV. (Option C) (Options A & D ruled out)
  • In hypokalemia, cells lose more potassium ions due to leaky channels.
  • The loss of positive charge increases the negative charge within the cell, causing hyperpolarization. (Option B ruled out)

Effect on Neuron Excitability
  • Increased excitability can lead to spontaneous firing and even cell death.
  • Persistent depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing action potential generation.
  • Decreased excitability occurs as the membrane potential is further from the threshold for action potential.
  • Hypokalemia also inhibits the Na-K-ATPase pump.

Hypocalcemia:

  • When blood calcium is normal or high, calcium remains bound to the extracellular mouth of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, stabilizing them.
  • Low blood Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) causes calcium to detach from the channel, leading to easier sodium entry. This detachment increases Na⁺ channel sensitivity, enhancing excitability and action potential generation.
  • Calcium and magnesium act as membrane stabilizers.
  • Hyperkalemia can eventually lead to increased activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump as a compensatory mechanism; this is not a direct or immediate effect on the RMP.

questions.text:
Arrange the following parts of the sarcomere from the periphery to center.


	Z line
	M line
	A band
	H zone
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) 1,3,4,2

Explanation:

  • A band: The dark band, anisotropic to polarized light. It contains the entire length of the myosin filaments. The ends of the actin filaments also overlap with the myosin filaments in this band.
  • I band: The light band, isotropic to polarized light. It contains only actin filaments.
  • Z disk: A structure composed of filamentous proteins (alpha-actinin) that bisects the I band. Actin filaments attach to the Z disk and extend from it in both directions to interdigitate with myosin filaments. Z disks also pass from myofibril to myofibril, attaching them together across the muscle fiber.
  • H zone: Located at the center of the A band, this zone contains only myosin filaments and appears lighter than the rest of the A band.
  • M line: A structure that runs down the center of the H zone, providing structural support for the myosin filaments.

questions.text:
Assertion: RMP depends on proteins and phosphate ions.

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst equation.

Choose the best statement regarding the assertion and reason.

choices.text: Both true, Reason is not the explanation of assertion
Both true, Reason is the explanation of assertion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option A) Both true, Reason is not the explanation of assertion

Explanation:

  • The assertion states that the resting membrane potential (RMP) depends on proteins and phosphate ions. This is true because the RMP is primarily maintained by the selective permeability of the cell membrane to different ions, such as potassium (K+), sodium (Na+), chloride (Cl-), and negatively charged proteins. These ions contribute to the electrical charge across the membrane and affect the RMP.
  • The Nernst equation calculates the Nernst potential (EMF) for a single, univalent ion (an ion with a +1 or -1 charge) at normal body temperature (37°C)

  • The Nernst potential magnitude depends on the ion concentration ratio across the membrane; larger differences result in higher potentials.
  • The diffusion potential contributes to the overall electrical potential difference across the membrane, including the RMP.
  • Therefore, both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

questions.text: The diagram displays nerve cell physiology. The event marked by 3 to 4 is due to _______ ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option C) K+ exiting the cell

Explanation: The event marked between 3 to 4  is Early repolarisation  where voltage gated  K+ channels  are fully open resulting in K+ exiting the cell.

  • Resting Membrane Potential (Point A on graph):
    • At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV.
    • K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels.
    • However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low.
  • Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C): (Options A and D ruled out)
    • Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels.
    • Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope.
  • Peak of Action Potential (Point C):
    • Na+ permeability is at its maximum.
    • K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak.
  • Early Repolarization Phase (Point D): (Option C)
    • Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability. K+ moves exits the cell.
    • Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase.
  • Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F): (Option C)
    • K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state.
    • Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of hyperpolarization, where the membrane potential falls slightly below the resting potential (Point F).

questions.text: Which of the following components is absent in smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Troponin

Explanation:

  • Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.
  • In striated muscles, troponin is a calcium-binding protein that regulates muscle contraction.
  • In smooth muscle, this function is performed by calmodulin, another calcium-binding protein. Calmodulin binds calcium and activates myosin light-chain kinase, which then phosphorylates myosin and facilitates contraction.

Characteristic features of Smooth muscles and Skeletal muscles:

Smooth muscles

Skeletal muscles

Spindle-shaped, single nucleated cells.

Multiple nucleated cells.

Neuromuscular junction is not present.

Proper neuromuscular junction is present.

Caveolae is present.

T-tubule is present.

Predominantly, calcium channels are present.

Predominantly, sodium channels are present.
  • Actin and myosin are present but not properly organised. (Options A and B)
  • Tropomyosin is present and plays a role in regulating the interaction between actin and myosin. (Option C)

 

Actin and myosin are properly organised.

A dense body is present.

The Z- line is present.
  • Calmodulin is present, and Titin is absent.
  • Troponin is absent

 

Troponin and Titin are present.

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for the detachment of the myosin head from actin?

choices.text: Entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Binding of ATP:

  • The detachment of the myosin head from actin occurs when ATP (adenosine triphosphate) binds to the myosin head. This binding causes a conformational change in the myosin molecule, leading to the release of myosin from actin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: The entry of calcium play a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction by binding to troponin, which leads to the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin.

Option C - Change in troponin C configuration: This process is responsible for the attachment of the actin-myosin during muscle contraction by uncoiling the troponin I from the tropomysoin.

Option D - Release of ADP and Pi: The release of ADP (adenosine diphosphate) and inorganic phosphate (Pi) occurs after the myosin head has formed a cross-bridge with actin and undergone a power stroke.

questions.text: What is the primary function of acetylcholine in the nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Inducing muscle contraction:

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in the nervous system, particularly in the transmission of signals between nerve cells and in the communication between nerves and muscles. One of its primary functions is to stimulate muscle contraction by transmitting signals across the neuromuscular junction. Upon release from nerve endings, acetylcholine binds to receptors on muscle cells, leading to the generation of an action potential and ultimately causing muscle contraction.
  • Therefore, option (a) "Inducing muscle contraction" is the correct choice.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inhibiting neurotransmission: Acetylcholine generally acts as an excitatory neurotransmitter in the nervous system, promoting the transmission of nerve impulses rather than inhibiting it.

Option C - Promoting bone growth: While acetylcholine receptors are present in bone cells, there is no evidence to suggest that acetylcholine plays a significant role in promoting bone growth.

Option  D - Regulating blood sugar levels: Acetylcholine does not directly regulate blood sugar levels. Insulin and glucagon, produced by the pancreas, are the primary hormones involved in blood sugar regulation.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on the conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Na+, K+:

  • Sodium and Potassium are two essential ions involved in the generation and conduction of action potentials in neurons. Sodium plays a crucial role in depolarization, while potassium contributes to repolarization and restoring the resting membrane potential.
  • A - It is Na+ ion, characterized by rapid influx of Na+ through fast type of voltage gated Na+ channels leading to sudden rise in action potential.
  • B - It is K+ ions, characterized by slow and steady efflux of K+ ion through a slow type of voltage gated K+ channel leading to slow decrease in membrane potential.

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of an electrical synapse?

choices.text: Pre and postsynaptic neurons are connected through gap junctions
The direction of impulse is unidirectional
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
The direction of impulse in bidirectional

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The direction of impulse is unidirectional:

  • In an electrical synapse, however, the impulse can flow bidirectionally, allowing for direct electrical communication between the neurons in both directions.

Characteristic

Electrical Synapse

Chemical Synapse

Illustration

Occurrence

Rare
  • Recreate this image
  • Mostly present in the CNS

Components

Presynaptic neuron and postsynaptic neuron
  • Presynaptic neuron and postsynaptic neuron

Synaptic Cleft Width

Narrow (2-4 nm, average 4 nm)
  • Wide (20-40 nm)

Pre-synaptic Terminals

No neurotransmitter-containing vesicles
  • Contains neurotransmitter-containing vesicles

Channels

Gap junctions between presynaptic and postsynaptic neuron
  • No gap junctions

Synaptic Transmission

Action potential (Na+) from the presynaptic membrane can easily pass through the gap junctions to the postsynaptic membrane without any synaptic delay.
  • Release of neurotransmitters from the presynaptic neuron; the neurotransmitter gets attached to the receptor on the post-synaptic membrane.
  • This will lead to the release of either Ca++ or Na+ ions, leading to the generation of an action potential in the post-synaptic neuron.
  • There will be an average synaptic delay of 0.5 milliseconds (0.3 to 5 milliseconds) due to multiple steps at the level of synaptic transmission.

Transmission Direction

Bidirectional
  • Unidirectional (from presynaptic to postsynaptic)

Location

Mainly found in the Inferior Olivary Nucleus (ION), Thalamus, Hypothalamus, Cortex
  • Distributed throughout the CNS

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Integrin connects with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fibronectin:

  • Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a large glycoprotein present in the extracellular matrix. It forms a fibrous network and acts as a scaffold for cells. Fibronectin interacts with integrins, particularly integrin α5β1 and integrin αvβ3, among others. This interaction is important for cell adhesion, migration, and signaling. Fibronectin also plays a role in tissue development, wound healing, and cell-matrix interactions.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Cadherins: Mediate calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion, forming adherens junctions crucial for tissue organization and cell signaling.

Option B - Vitronectin: Interacts with integrins, particularly αvβ3 and αvβ5, facilitating cell adhesion, migration, and signaling in various tissues.

Option D - Selectins: Aid leukocyte recruitment during inflammation by mediating rolling adhesion on endothelial cells, facilitating interaction with inflammatory molecules.

questions.text: What is the primary source of energy used by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP during a 100-meter dash?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phosphocreatine:

  • During rapid strenuous activity like 100-meter dash the demand of ATP is covered by anaerobic glycolysis due to reduced oxygen availability.
  • Phosphocreatine (anaerobic glycolysis) is a high-energy phosphate compound that is stored in skeletal muscles. During high-intensity activities like sprinting, it can rapidly donate a phosphate group to ADP (adenosine diphosphate), regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). This provides a quick source of energy without the need for oxygen or extensive metabolic pathways.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Aerobic glycolysis: Aerobic glycolysis refers to the breakdown of glucose in the presence of oxygen to produce ATP. This process occurs in the cytoplasm of cells and involves a series of enzymatic reactions. It is an important energy pathway during prolonged endurance activities when oxygen is readily available.

Option C and D: Fatty acids and tryglycerides are the primary fuel source for aerobic metabolism. During low-intensity and long-duration activities, such as distance running, the body relies on the oxidation of fatty acids to generate ATP.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the consistent amplitude of action potential when the stimulus is delivered at an intensity above the threshold?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - All or none law:

  • The all-or-none law states that once a nerve or muscle cell is stimulated beyond a certain threshold, it will generate an action potential of consistent magnitude.
  • If the stimulus is strong enough, the resulting action potential will have a fixed amplitude and will propagate without loss of intensity. Below the threshold, no action potential occurs; above it, the response is maximal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Local potential: Local potential refers to the passive changes in membrane potential that occur during the propagation of electrical signals along a neuron.

Option C - Absolute refractory period: Absolute refractory period refers to a brief period after an action potential when the neuron is unresponsive to further stimulation. During this period, another action potential cannot be generated, regardless of the strength of the stimulus.

Option D - Relative refractory period: Relative refractory period refers to a period following the absolute refractory period during which a neuron can be stimulated to generate another action potential, but only with a stronger stimulus than the previous stimulus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a calcium-binding protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Clathrin:

  • Clathrin is not a calcium-binding protein. It is a structural protein that plays a crucial role in the formation of coated vesicles during endocytosis, a process by which cells internalize molecules from the extracellular environment. Clathrin helps shape the vesicles by assembling them into a lattice-like structure around the invaginated membrane.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Calbindin: Calbindin is a calcium-binding protein that regulates calcium homeostasis in cells. It is found in various tissues, including the brain, kidney, and intestines, and helps buffer and transport calcium ions.

Option B - Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a highly conserved calcium-binding protein found in The smooth muscle cell.

Option C - Troponin: Troponin is a complex of three subunits (troponin C, troponin I, and troponin T) found in skeletal muscle cells and is a calcium binding protein.

questions.text: Which of the following options has the slowest conduction velocity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Postganglionic sympathetic fibers:

  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibers have the least conduction velocity compared to the other options as these are unmyelinated fibers. These fibers are part of the autonomic nervous system and transmit signals from the autonomic ganglia to target organs, such as smooth muscles, cardiac muscles, and glands.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These fibers have a higher conduction velocity than postganglionic sympathetic fibers of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.text: The resting membrane potential of nerve fiber is close to the isoelectric potential of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chloride ions:

  • The resting membrane potential of a nerve fiber is equal to the equilibrium potential of chloride ion i.e., -70 mV.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.
